 Abstract The central purpose of the paper is to analyze various forms of government intervention in the loan market in terms of their effect on efficiency. This provides the essential basis for evaluating and judging these policies. It also shows where earlier policy prescriptions are correct, incomplete or wrong. One of the implications of the paper is that the credit market differs fundamentally from the market for ordinary goods and services. Consequently conventional analysis of the loan markets, based on theory applicable to these goods, can be misleading even when similar prescriptions are reached. This is because the similarity may be restricted to special circumstances. Another important highlight of the paper is the vital role of collateral in the loan market. These two issues are addressed in the introductory discussion on the special nature of credit markets, which forms an important prerequisite for understanding the subsequent section and the rest of the paper. The selective literature review is designed primarily for readers who require a bridge between the existing literature and the current model. It therefore surveys the assumptions and limitations of these models and indicates how the assumptions are made more realistic in the current model. The reader uninterested in such details can skip this section without loss of continuity.  I. INTRODUCTION AND SUMMARY OF RESULTS 1.1 General Background and the Problem to be Addressed Almost all countries have, or have had until recently, controls on deposit and loan interest rates. In most developing countries and many developed countries there are legal limits on maximum interest rates chargeable in general or to special categories of borrowers. Where legal limits do not exist, the same purpose has been achieved through informal limits enforced by discount policy and other indirect methods.!' Governments have also subsidized or enforced cross-subsidization of loan rates to different categories of borrowers, different maturities of loans or for different usage. A similar history exists for differential limits on credit expansion and forced allocation of credit to different categories of borrowers.!/ Even though there has been a tendency to reduce or eliminate such intervention in developed countries, many forms of intervention remain. Such intervention by developing country governments has increased considerably over the past ten years.  9 Three very broad underlying reasons for government intervention can be discerned; these are first market failure or imperfections in the credit market and the related question of distribution of gains between borrowers and lenders. Second, market failure or imperfections in other markets which might necessitate, or make it useful to, intervene in the credit market. And third, broader economy wide questions of equity and divergence of social from private optimality. The present paper will focus exclusively on the first of these reasons. That is, what are the causes and consequences of market failure or market imperfections in the credit market? What is the effect of different government policies and different government interventions when such failures and imperfections exist (and also when they are thought to exist but actually don't)? This forms the basis for defining situations under which government intervention may be justified and for evaluating different policies for correcting such imperfections. In examining credit markets it is useful to separate issues concerned with the deposit side of the market from the loan side. The former is concerned intimately with the important issue of incentives and disincentives for savings. The present paper will not address this issue. It assumes the deposit side of the market as given. On the loan side of the market the paper does not directly consider the question of pure consumption loans, though it has implications for this issue. The focus is on the business loan market or loans for production (and distribution) purposes. However loans to agricultural households, where it may not be possible to distinguish between use for production and use for consumption, fall directly within the purview of the paper.
 10 1.2 Selective Review of the Literature Given the long history of government intervention in credit markets one might expect a vast literature on the optimality or non-optimality of financial markets, the possible sources of inefficiency and the appropriate policy responses. The literature is somewhat disappointing. It is based essentially on two sets of opposing beliefs. The first set draws its inspiration from the traditional neoclassical model.5/ In this view there is no problem to be solved. If anything it is government intervention which creates problems. If governments lift all restrictions, the market will optimally allocate funds among different categories of borrowers. At the other extreme is the institutional view,!' which posits that many less developed countries are characterized by a feudal market structure and an exploitative landlord tenant relationship extracts surplus from farmers through usurious interest rates. The only way to correct this situation is to sweep away the credit and other institutions which give rise to it. With respect to the developing countries the literature has focussed, till quite recently, on rural credit markets and the question of whether interest rates are 'too high and the reasons for this. An institutional variation of the traditional neoclassical model postulates highly fragmented credit markets that are, in effect, hundreds of isolated markets each characterized by a traditional monopolist.!/ The issue then becomes whether in each such sub-market there exist enough lenders to make the market competitive. However the question remains why credit markets are more fragmented than other markets, such as those for labor, output and urban goods, as it would seem much easier to physically move funds around than these other goods and services. If the answer is that all markets are fragmented then one is led to the institutional solution of wholesale reform. If the
 answer is that, the other markets are not fragmented then one returns to the problem, why credit markets are more monopolisticl8/ We will show subsequently that the credit market is a very unique market and inherently different from markets for other goods. This tends to produce situations which are neither 'competitive' nor 'monopolistic' but may be characterized as a "competitive monopoly". This word is chosen in preference to the usual monopolistic-competition because the market is different in significant ways from typical conditions of monopolistic competition. Another variation of the traditional neoclassical model is to introduce transaction costs of intermediation. Again intermediaries exist between producers and consumers of virtually all goods, and it is not clear why such costs should play a more important role in credit than in other markets. In the context of lending to small enterprises however, differential transaction costs provide a plausible explanation for differences in lending patterns by informal and formal banks.2/ Informal banks are postulated to have lower transaction costs on average in lending to smaller firms than organized banks. This could result in a greater proportion, as compared to the organized banks, of informal banks loans going to small enterprises. The evidence on this is however inconclusive. The administrative costs for lending by both types of banks to small firms seems to be approximately the 10/ same.-L The framework is extended to include bad debts or defaults as a constituent of total transaction cost. With this extension, the evidence does offer some support for the hypothesis that urban informal lenders and organized commercial banks have different transaction costs for this given category of borrowers.-1/ Opposing implications have however been drawn from this analysis; the traditional neoclassical one is to allow both informal and

However it is often found that opening of such branches makes little difference to the terms and amount of loans to most categories of borrowers who are the focus of government interest. The reason for this will become clearer when the competitive monopoly model is analyzed. We turn briefly to the literature which has arisen in the context of developed country credit markets. The dominant issue in this literature has been whether credit rationing can exist in free markets characterized by rational profit maximizing banks.L6/ Borrowing is for either of two purposes, what may be termed productive business, and financial investment. The latter which includes borrowing for purchase of financial securities, bonds etc. in a perfectly competitive market for such securities, is not of major importance to LDCs and therefore need not be reviewed here. For productive business,
 14 where investment opportunities are specific to the borrower, only a special type of borrowing is considered in which a fixed amount of investment K is required. Further the focus is on new investments. It is assumed that the returns from this investment are uncertain and that repayment varies continuously with the realized returns, when returns are insufficient to provide full repayment. This contrasts with the model reviewed earlier where there were only two possibilities, full repayment or no repayment. Here different amounts of repayment are possible, each having a probability assigned to it. This is clearly more realistic. The literature concludes that the supply curve of the lender for a borrower represented by such a repayment schedule will be backward bending. The reasoning is that given the fixed nature of the investment and the pattern of returns, there is a ceiling on total repayment. Beyond a certain point a higher interest rate doesn't lead to higher repayment and it does not pay the bank to give a larger loan. From this the implication is drawn that if the demand curve of the borrower lies entirely outside the supply curve, rationing will result. Among the limitation of the fixed investment requirement is the implicit assumption of fixed co-efficient production technology. It also seems to exclude short term and commercial loans which form the major portion of total bank loans even in developed countries. There is also an apparent contradiction on the demand side. The credit rationing literature assumes that the shortfall between the fixed capital requirement (K) and the loan (L) is made up by firm equity contribution (E). That is E = K - Ls. However after all the analysis, it is assumed that the loan demand curve can arbitrarily lie outside it and the firm's equity is greater than desired by the owner (s) i.e. E > K - LD where sub-scripts D and S represent demand and supply. This implies that the equity market is imperfect and that the
 15 firm expects the bank to make a commitment greater than the owner(s) feels is optimal for himself. The basic problem is that not only loan supply but also loan demand must depend on the uncertain return from the project.17/ Most papers also either implicitly assume a monopolist lender, or leave the entire market structure on the loan side unclear. Finally, the papers do not say anything about the optimality or efficiency of the market and the effects of government intervention in the market. All these issues will be dealt with in the present paper. In analysing loans for financial investment, Azzi and Cox (1976) consider the role of equity and collateral in credit markets which is not explicitly considered in earlier models. They introduce collateral into the model as a price like variable similar to the loan interest rate. In effect, both collateral and firm equity affect the quality of the loan from the perspective of the lender.i-! In the market for business loans considered in the present paper, this may be true for equity. However collateral has a much more complex role, that of equilibrating the market, and is therefore intimately linked to the question of competition and degree of monopoly. 19/ Finally, Jaffee and Russell (1976) develop a model of the consumer credit market which explicitly considers the inability of the lender to distinguish between honest and dishonest borrowers or alternatively between higher and lower income borrowers. They show that a competitive market will either be heavily rationed or will be unstable. They hypothesize that instability may be eliminated through the emergence of a monopoly. In the present paper we will also consider these problems in the context of a business loan market, and show that a stable non-rationed market can exist, but is likely to be inefficient. This leads naturally to the question of alternative government policies to correct the situation.
 16 1.3 The Special Nature of the Credit Market It is useful to start a discussion of the credit market by looking at the traditional neoclassical model of the competitive economy which underlies most analysis. The market for funds is conceived to be like the market for any good or service, with the supply of savings constituting the supply curve for loans, and the demand for funds for investment and consumption purposes constituting the demand curve for loans. There is no explicit role for financial intermediation, as the market smoothly transfers funds from savers to investors and consumers. Intermediaries do exist between producers of goods and the ultimate consumers. One way they have been explicitly considered, is by imagining a good at the producers location as a different one from that available to the consumer. Wholesalers, retailers etc are then seen as transforming goods from one form into another. For most purposes this is a reasonably satisfactory solution where ordinary goods and services are concerned. For a bank, acting as a financial intermediary, and receiving deposits and making loans at the same location, or costlessly transmitting funds between different branches, this seems a patently contrived solution. It does however alert us to the fact that there are really two markets here, not one as postulated by the simple savings-investment model. On one side is the market for deposits, with a supply curve given by the traditional savings side of the market, and a demand curve constituting the demand for loanable funds by banks. On the other side is the market for loans, with a supply curve depending on banks and a demand curve aggregated over individual borrowers.2!/ There is a fundamental difference between either of these two markets for funds, and the corresponding market for a good. In any goods market there is a simultaneous exchange of value; the payment for the good is
 17 made at the same time as the supply of the good-21! It is a fundamental feature of the credit market, that the payment for the 'good' is made at a later date than that at which the 'good' is supplied-22/ On the deposit side of the market, the good consists of the savings or other deposits and the payment consists of interest plus principal. On the loan side the 'good' is the loan amount the repayment is the principal plus interest. In both cases the good is exchanged for a commitment, to pay a specified sum or sums in the future. Clearly the actual realization of the commitment depends both on the ability and the intentions of the individual or firm making the commitment. Uncertainty about both these aspects therefore plays a fundamental role in the credit market.23/ To illustrate this from the deposit side of the market we have to go back to an era before central bank chartering and monitoring of banks and of public deposit insurance corporations. Depositors' uncertainty about a bank's ability to repay clearly had an influence on their willingness to deposit money, with the phenomenon of a 'run on a bank' arising when their judgment changed. Such uncertainty, particularly the possibility of a bank (or banks) going bankrupt can exert a strong influence on the supply curve of savings. In poor underdeveloped countries where banking institutions are not well established, savings may still be influenced by such uncertainty. However as this is not the focus of our analysis, we return to the loan side of the market. Assume for the moment that all actual and potential borrowers are perfectly honest and fully intend to repay the loan if they are able to. That is, there are no questions about the intent to repay the loan (or pay for the 'good'). Assume also that there are a large number of identical banks,24/ so that there are no problems of monopoly or oligopoly. Because each borrower's
 18 return from productive activity and, consequently, his ability to repay is different, there must be a different supply curve for each borrower. In the neoclassical goods market the identity of the sellers or the buyers is of no relevance to the transaction.1k' All that matters is that the former have a good to sell and the latter the means to pay for it. In the credit market there is no simple market supply curve for loans but a number of individual- specific supply curves. For practical purposes we may lump together a number of potential borrowers with approximately similar pattern of returns and repayment ability. For simplicity assume that within a class the borrowers are identical, so that borrowers can be divided into a (smaller) number of classes. Assuming further that within each class there are a large number of borrowers, it is reasonable to talk about a supply curve for loans to this class of borrowers and a demand curve from these borrowers. However, it is still more fruitful to think in terms of a representative bank's supply curve for a single representative borrower and that borrower's demand curve. This is because, ultimately the loan transaction is between a specific bank and a specific borrower, and we are less likely to loose sight of the many assumptions made in the process of going from this to aggregative supply and demand curves for the class. From this point it is useful to focus on the nature of business loans. The borrower in this case is a firm, be it an incorporated firm or an unincorporated entrepreneur or trader. The loan is to be used directly for production or trade (as distinct from financial investments), the returns from which are uncertain. These returns depend inter alia upon the nature of the productive activity, the capital required, the industry in which the firm operates, and the ability of its managers. Other characteristics of the firm, such as invested equity, affect the prospects of loan repayment, for any given
 19 realization of returns to the firm. Thus for example, of two firms which ended up with the same returns, the one with higher equity would have greater capacity to repay the loan. In analyzing the loan market it is useful to adopt the partial equilibrium approach in which we take all other factors/characteristics as given while determining the factors endogenous to the market. The loan amount (L) and the loan interest rate (r) are obviously two such variables. The third most vital variable, which is often neglected, is collateral (C), and this plays a role unique in the credit market. To appreciate this role of collateral consider a hypothetical situation in which collateral value, C, completely covered the value of the loan plus interest, that is (1+r)L = C.26/ This market would be essentially indistinguishable from a goods market because, in effect there is a simultaneous exchange of goods of equal value. Uncertainty about the returns to the firm from productive activity and its ability to repay would become irrelevant to the loan market.Z./ Practical observation of both informal and formal credit markets shows that loans are often made without any collateral at all. Typically there are various amounts of collateral taken, with perhaps the complete coverage case occuring occasionally at the other extreme. The very fact that uncertainty about the variables mentioned earlier plays a vital role in the credit market suggest that collateral must be only one of the variables constituting the terms of the equilibrium loan contract between the firm and bank. To understand the precise role of collateral in the loan market one must re-examine the nature of competitive equilibrium in a single goods market. This market is characterized by a supply schedule in which the quantity supplied is a function of market price, and a demand schedule in which quantity demanded is a function of the market price. Equilibrium is
 20 defined as the intersection of the two curves, or the single price at which quantity demanded equals quantity supplied. Competitive equilibrium however entails something further. It is recognized that at the demand-supply equilibrium there may be positive 'pure profits'. Competitive equilibrium requires that existing firms (or at least the marginal firm), earn zero profit. This is brought about by the entry and exit of firms, which shifts the supply curve to the right or left at each price as the total supply is correspondingly increased or reduced. In the loan market, for any given value of collateral, we can similarly obtain a supply locus relating loan supply to the loan interest rate, and a demand locus relating loan demand to the interest rate. As before, for any given collateral, equilibrium is defined as the intersection of the two curves. At first sight the collateral value appears to be indeterminate, as long as it lies between zero and the value of loan plus interest, as, for each such value we have an equilibrium. However, even in the extreme case in which there are several identical firms and several identical banks, the loan transaction is ultimately a transaction between one firm and one bank. In this situation as long as the number of banks is 'high enough' so that they act as 'perfect competitors' a change in the number of banks has no effect on the amount a given bank is willing to loan to the particular firm, at the announced interest rate and collateral value, i.e. there is no shift in the supply curve for the given firm or for any other firm from the class. A change in the collateral value, however, does shift the supply curve, and also changes the expected profits of the bank making the loan.18/ Competitive equilibrium can then be conceived off as being established by changes in the collateral value which result in zero expected profits for the bank making the loan. At this point no competing (identical) bank can offer better terms, for this would entail expected
 21 losses. In other words there is a unique value of the loan interest rate and collateral value for which the market is in competitive equilibrium (given the usual types of assumptions needed to ensure uniqueness of equilibrium). As the question of monopoly in credit markets has played such an important role in the literature on LDC credit markets we must consider how a monopolistic loan market differs fundamentally from monopolistic goods markets. Maintaining all earlier assumptions except that there is now only one bank in a region. This bank has access to the urban or foreign capital market so that it faces a perfectly elastic supply of deposits (it is still a competitor on the deposit side of the market). The previous analysis suggests that the traditional diagram of monopoly in the goods market is not applicable.29/ It has already been noted that there are many values of collateral at which demand and supply loci intersect, and one such intersection constitutes the competitive equilibrium. This suggests that another such equilibria may be the monopoly equilibrium 30/ One can think of collateral as a transfer of value from the bank to the firm. This not only increases the expected profits of the bank making the loan, but correspondingly reduces the expected profits of the firm. If one starts from the competitive equilibrium value of collateral, as defined earlier, and increases it, eventually there would be a point at which the borrowing firm's expected profits would be reduced to an amount which it would make even without taking the loan (say P ). A marginal increase in collateral would mean an expected net loss to it from taking the loan, and its demand for loans would then be zero. The point of equivalence represents the loan terms at which the bank is making the greatest possible profits from the loan transaction (with the given firm), and this can be defined as the monopoly equilibrium. lWe will show later that the degree of monopoly or oligopoly can

The greater the relative bank pessimism the higher the interest rate. Even accounting for differences in collateral required, the' terms that the
 24 more pessimistic bank can offer will be worse in the sense that the firm's expected profits are lower. Imagine all these banks competing against, each other to obtain this firm's business. Given the firm's demand curve, there is an equilibrium value of loan size at these terms and an associated value of expected profits for the firm, say P Banks 3 to n cannot offer better terms than these because this would imply negative expected profits for them. It does not need to offer the best possible terms that it can. There is in effect an element of implicit monopoly profits accruing to the bank. However these profits are not in general merely short term profits. Unlike monopolistic-competition in the goods market, they do not depend on cost differences or on wrong perceptions about how other sellers will react. However to

In deriving these implications we will often make the assumption that the closer are the information links between a firm and a bank the smaller is the gap between their respective expectations about the productive activity for which the loan is taken. There are two aspects to these information links. The most obvious is that flows of information will depend on the channels of communication, including personal contacts, and on the judgment by the bank of the reliability of such channels. The second aspect is the bank's interpretation of whatever information is received. This in turn depends on the expertise (knowledge) of the bank and the firm and the similarity and differences in their general experience and outlook. As an illustration, consider a lender who in the past (or at present) operated as a firm in a particular industry, or alternatively has many friends and relatives operating in this industry. We would expect his information links with the industry to be strong. The same would be true if he has done a lot of lending to firms in this industry. On a firm specific basis we would expect a lender who has dealt with a potential borrower as a supplier of inputs, buyer of output or belongs to the same caste or kin group to have stronger information links with this borrower.37/ A similar result would follow if the lender has dealt with the potential borrower as a depositor or has provided him with other banking servicesA38/ The analysis of this paper suggests that if market 'fragmentation' is important in LDC credit markets it is this fragmentation in the flow and interpretation of information which is at the root of it. Though these information problems may play a role in goods and service markets they have a
 26 much more important role in credit markets because information and expectations are fundamental to the lending process.39/ It has been assumed, so far, that the borrowing firm's intentions are perfectly above-board and honest. It is obvious to anyone familiar with bank operations that judgments about the ability of the firm are supplemented by those about its sincerity. The special problems which arise, and which are not present in the goods market,40/ can be illustrated by a simple case in which there are two types of firms: one perfectly honest and the other completely dishonest. It never pays the latter to repay the loan as long as collateral is less than principal plus interest. On the other hand for the honest firm the optimal collateral is in general less than the principal plus interest. The problem can then be framed as an inability by banks to distinguish between the two types of firms in a given class of borrowers. The banks have some judgment about the proportion of honest firms in the class or the probability that any given firm is honest. Compared to a hypothetical situation in which honest borrowers could be perfectly distinguished the actual equilibrium is one in which these borrowers receive smaller loans at higher interest rates. The expected profits of the bank from dishonest borrowers are negative. This means that the average repayment per borrower, all coming from the honest borrowers, is reduced so that the supply curve for loans shifts to the left. From a slightly different perspective the presence of dishonest borrowers imposes a negative externality on honest borrowers whose expected profits are consequently reduced. In the extreme case in which the banks feel that the proportion of honest borrowers is too low, the terms become so bad that they drive out the honest borrowers completely, and no loans are made.
 27 Information problems are an important feature of the credit market. In addition to the inability to distinguish between honest and dishonest borrowers, banks have difficulty in distinguishing between more - and less - productive borrowers, more and less risky borrowers, and between use of loan for production or consumption purposes (as in agricultural households). In each case the loans are supplied on terms which are an average of the two types which results in worsening the terms to and harming the more profitable (from the banks' perspective). There are ways of correcting some of these problems where the social benefit exceeds the private benefit, so that government intervention is desirable and necessary as is shown in chapters VI and VII. 1.4 Summary of Results and Implications The paper provides a unified framework for analyzing credit markets, and allows apparently disparate observations and facts in the banking and institutional literature to be understood and interpreted. More importantly it provides a unique framework for determining the effect of government policy on credit market efficiency. The paper starts by making as many simplifying assumptions as possible without eliminating the basic features of the market. In suceeding chapters these assumptions are relaxed one by one to see the effect on market equilibrium. In each case an attempt is made to draw out the many implications of each result, to analyze policy implications and to judge the usefulness of government policy intervention. Before summarizing the results it is necessary to provide some definitions. The borrower (referred to as the firm) is assumed to borrow funds from the lender (referred to as the bank) for productive purposes. The returns from this productive activity is uncertain. The firm and all banks have some subjective judgment or
 28 expectations about the pattern of this uncertainty (the probability distribution of returns). We will say that the banks have more pessimistic expectations than the firm when the mean value they ascribe to these uncertain returns is less than that ascribed by the firm. Variance or spread may also differ in certain ways but this is not important in the present context. Put differently, the banks' judgment of the firm's productivity is less than the firm's own judgment about its productivity. "Identical expectations" means that the firm and all banks have the same judgment-A-Y Differential expectations are defined to mean that the given firm's judgment is different from the banks', but all the banks have the same judgment 42/ In chapter III, it is shown that in an efficiently functioning credit market the expected marginal product from the use of a loan must equal the opportunity cost of funds, earlier called the deposit interest rate (i), to the lender plus the marginal costs variable part of transaction cost, (t) of transferring these funds to the firm. Interestingly, neither of these need be equal to the loan interest rate (r). Contrary to the popular conception the loan interest rate is not the sole cost of the loan to the borrower. The cost or price of the loan has two dimensions, comprised of the loan interest rate and the collateral. 43/ The above efficiency condition can be used directly to determine whether any firm or group of firms is getting the 'right' amount of loan (if i and t can be determined). Associated with this condition is the optimal loan size. It is shown that this is independent of the fixed elements of the bank's and the firm's transaction costs, the degree of uncertainty and the degree of monopoly-! The last only effects the distribution of gains between bank and firm or their relative gains from the loan transaction. The reason for this is that given identical expectations, both participants agree that this generates the greatest expected surplus for
 29 division between repayment and firm profits. If both bank and firm have identical expectations but are over-optimistic compared to some 'true' value, this can mean that a loan transaction takes place when it shouldn't 45/ Similarly if they are both too pessimistic no loan may be given when it should.46/ In a competitive equilibrium with identical expectations the loan interest rate is shown to be inversely related to the firm's equity. If the firm's owner(s) recognizes this link between his (their) equity in the firm and his (their) loan terms, and carries out a simultaneous determination of his (their) equity contribution and loan demand, the equity decision is also efficient whether or not a perfect equity market exists. However, the assumptions of identical expectations and risk neutrality limit the generality of this result. It is possible to define a category of prime borrowers for whom the equilibrium collateral value is zero. These are likely to be the least risky and most well established customers, which have the lowest transaction costs. The interest rate charged to these borrowers sets a lower limit on interest rates; The bank should not be expected to charge a lower rate to any other customer, if allocational efficiency in the credit market is to be obtained. The monopoly case presents two noteworthy differences. An increase in the firm's equity, or a decrease in the opportunity cost of funds to the market, does not lead to better terms for the firm. It merely brings about an adjustment in the loan rate and collateral demand, with the expected profits of the firm remaining unchanged. This is because the monopolist is able to extract any surplus generated by the loan transaction whatever the exogenous conditions. This offers some support for the suspicion in the institutional literature that the existence of complete monopoly reduces the
 30 incentive to introduce technical innovations with large minimum capital requirements (K). For those whose available equity is less than this requirement, there would be virtually no incentive to make such an investment as almost the entire surplus would go to the monopoly bank.47/ Chapter IV considers the "differential expectations" case, in which the firm's expectations can differ from those of the banks. This is shown to lead to inefficiency. If the banks are more pessimistic than the firm, the supply locus shifts adversely along the demand locus so that the loan interest rate is higher and the loan amount lower than optimal. Other things being equal, the greater the degree of monopoly,48/ the higher the interest rate and collateral requirements. The loan amount is no longer independent of the degree of monopoly. There are two cases: the conventional case, consistent with traditional analysis, in which the loan size decreases with degree of monopoly (so that the existence of monopoly causes efficiency); and the unconventional case, in which the opposite happens. In competitive equilibrium, the greater the banks' degree of pessimism relative to that of the firm, the greater the degree of inefficiency, and the lower the expected profit of the firm.49/ If this difference is large enough, it is possible for the loan terms to become so adverse that the expected profit of the firm becomes lower than it would be in the absence of any loan transaction. No such transaction will then take place, and the loan market will cease to exist for the firm or the class of firms. This result is independent of the 'true' productivity of the firm: it depends only on the difference between the firm's and the banks' judgment. Thus, some categories of firms may be excluded from the loan market purely because of the 'wrong' subjective judgment of the banks. Further, as no loan is made, no new information is generated about the productivity of the
 31 borrowers which might change perceptions. The situation may persist until an enterprising bank takes a chance or government policy intervenes. This may help to explain why organized, largely urban banks in developing countries do not lend to unorganized informal small firms, and agricultural borrowers. It may also explain low levels of long term lending, and of lending to new entreprenuers, new industries and those desiring to use sophisticated technology. Even if lending takes place, as in the case of non-traditional exports, the loans may be less than necessary and carry a high interest rate. Similar things happen when the economy is opened to international capital flows. Multinationals or large organized firms can obtain funds at international rates, but other firms are completely excluded from this market. In all these cases the problem is an assymetry in the amount of information available and the inability of the banks to evaluate relatively unfamiliar activities and methods of operations. Government policies can be used to correct this problem, however. It can be shown that a ceiling on interest rates compounds the problem instead of correcting it, or creates one if none existed before. Collateral requirements rise and the expected profits of the firm are reduced even further. The loan size falls further thus increasing inefficiency. If the firm's expected profits fall sufficiently, it may not find it profitable to take any loan. The imposition of minimum lending requirements for a class of firms also raises collateral requirements, reduces the firm's expected profits and may eliminate it from the market. If this does not happen however efficiency will be restored. The best way to correct the inefficiency arising from differential expectations is to introduce either an interest subsidy or a lump sum subsidy per loan. Either of these policies increases efficiency and moves the size of loans, interest rates and firms' expected profits in the
 32 right direction. In the case of 'monopoly', none of these four policy options can affect firm profits. In addition the fixed sum subsidy (per loan) has no effect on the equilibrium. The minimum lending requirement policy may therefore be preferred to the interest subsidy policy as it involves no subsidy to the monopolist. Alternatively, an interest subsidy may be accompanied by a lump sum tax on the monopolist, but this may not be a realistic option. The analysis of competitive equilibrium shows that credit ceilings can be justified in one case: one in which the credit market is functioning efficiently for only one group of firms, while all other firms are suffering from the inefficiency analyzed above. A credit ceiling on this group of firms would reduce their expected marginal product of loans, and bring them closer to the levels for all other firms. Earlier models implicitly assumed that loans or credit are for investment in a completely new project, and that the technology to be used was of the fixed co-efficient type. Further, in addition to the usual substitutability between labor and capital, recent studies demonstrate that working capital is an important independent factor of production. 11 The present model therefore assumes that the loan could be for a new project or an existing business, and for manufacturing, services, trade or agriculture. The lender must form some estimate of the likely repayment by a borrower for any given loan terms and different loan amounts at these terms. The pattern of repayment or the expected repayment can be seen as made up of two parts. One is the likely pattern of returns to the productive activity for which the loan is taken by the borrower. In general this return must depend on the size of the loan which, along with the borrower's own funds or equity contribution, constitutes the total capital of the. firm. Further, at the time the loan is made, this return is in general uncertain, and this is what leads to the uncertainty in repayment. CONCLUSIONS AND SUGGESTIONS FOR FURTHER WORK 8.1 Overview The paper defines efficiency in the business loan market in terms of the equality between the expected marginal product of the loan and the marginal cost of obtaining and transferring funds from bank depositors to bank borrowers. The importance of this definition is that it is independent of the degree of uncertainty in the returns from the productive activity for which the loan is desired, as long as banks and firms have identical perceptions about this uncertainty. In this case, efficiency is not affected by an increase in bank oligopoly or monopoly powers where such power is precisely and quantifiably defined by the model itself. It is also shown that effi- ciency in the loan market ensures efficiency in the equity decision if the loan and equity decisions are interlinked to take account of the effect of the latter on the contract terms of the former. There is underinvestment in equity, however, if this link is not made and the two decisions are made independently. By contrast, questions of the distribution of gains between borrower firms and lender banks are intimately related to the difference between the "true" productivity and the identical (by assumption) perceptions of the bank and firm. If the degree of perceived productivity is less than the "true" productivity, the bank benefits at the cost of the firm. Similarly, if the perceived productivity is greater than the actual or true productivity, the firm benefits at the cost of the bank. Therefore on an average banks would benefit from the principle of conservative judgment which is generally attributed to them, if they can convince firms to be equally conservative.
 - 134 - Even if the firms do not have the same conservative judgment, banks still gain relative to firms, if on average the firms' expectations are 'true' and those of the banks are pessimistic relative to the 'true' productivity. These distributional considerations can have important effects if saving and investment propensities of the bankers and owners of firms differ, but this question lies outside the scope of the present paper. One can speculate, however, that the remarkable growth of manufactured exports from Korea is at least partly due to the replacement of bank conservatism by optimism with respect to manufacturer - exporters under the direction of the government. The paper also shows that the degree of bank monopoly with respect to any group of borrowers (e.g. moneylenders and rural borrowers) also directly affects distributional equity. The greater the degree of monopoly, the greater the benefit to the bank at the cost of the firm. These distributional effects could have an effect on savings, investment and growth. The paper identifies three major causes of inefficiency in the loan market. The first relates to bank-firm differences in the perception of uncertainty with regard to productive returns. The second relates to moral hazards, or the inability of the bank to separate honest from dishonest borrowers. The third relates to adverse selection, or the inability of banks to distinguish between firms with greater and smaller mean returns. In all three situations, the extreme case of inefficiency is represented by the disppearance of the loan market for the group or sub-group of firms. In the first case, that of differential expectations, it is shown that under certain conditions the degree of 'monopoly' is directly related to the degree of inefficiency. There is also a possible but less likely case in which 'monopoly' actually reduces the degree of inefficiency. In either case,
 - 135 - however, certain government policies involving, e.g., lump sum subsidies, interest subsidies, collateral subsidies and forced lending can remove this inefficiency. The paper also shows that there are certain differences between the 'monopoly' and competitive situations in the relationship between loan interest rate and collateral; these can be used to test the model. The paper also analyzes the situation in which lack of acceptable collateral can lead to inefficiency, and excessive transaction costs can lead to the disappearance of the loan market. In the moral hazard and adverse selection cases, we defined a process of research and development in banking as the development of indicators to separate honest from dishonest borrowers. It was shown that the returns to private research may be significantly lower than the social returns in many cases. A strong case can therefore be made for government subsidies to research in this area. It was also shown that this may require linking such subsidies with forced lending to particular groups where the problem of moral hazard or adverse selection is acute. Similar support may also be useful in separating firms with different degrees of uncertainty in returns. The general model, termed competitive monopoly, is only briefly analyzed but has some interesting implications. It helps explain why accusations of monopoly profits by rural moneylenders in a less developed country may have some validity even when there are many such moneylenders in different villages in the same area. It also explains why the introduction of an organized urban bank into such an area may have no effect on the rural credit market. Where informal credit markets exist in developing countries, the model suggests conditions under which (and types of bankers for whom) it would be socially optimal to encourage them. This result contradicts to some

These will be considered briefly. Throughout the paper, changes in expectations were analyzed in terms of the pessimism factor, an increase in which implies an expectation of lower mean returns from productive activity. Another way in which expectational changes can be analyzed is in terms of the riskiness or spread of the distribution of the returns. These are referred to in the literature as mean preserving spreads. The analysis of changes in riskiness is more complicated, because in addition to all the cases analyzed it is also possible to get the opposite case. Thus for example, increased differences in perception of risk between banks and firms can decrease efficiency, as in the case of increases in the pessimism differential, but may also increase efficiency (depending on various functional forms and exogenous parameter values). Another major difference (which in effect follows from the above) is that, given the risk neutrality assumption throughout the paper, differences in risk perception, no matter how large, are unlikely to result in disappearance of the loan markets for the given firms. l/ There is still no rationing, however. This result is different from Stiglitz and Weiss (1981), who assume exogenously given collateral, equity, capital requirements (and consequently also loan size) and non-negative returns to the productive activity, and then show that rationing is possible.
 - 137 - 8.3 Non-perfect Market on the Deposit Side It is assumed in the paper that the bank can obtain unlimited funds at the deposit interest rate i. In most countries there are government imposed ceilings on this rate, which is usually fixed by the government. Consider the case in which this exogenous rate acts as a constraint on total savings. If we assume that total savings at this rate are exogenously divided up among the banks, as for example by free depositor choice, all the results of the model go through unchanged. All that happens is that the deposit rate i is replaced by a shadow cost of funds, say x , in the bank's loan decisions. The banks now earn monopoly profits on the deposit side equal to the difference between X and i multiplied by their total deposits. Loan decisions, though now based on X, have the same qualitative feature as those analyzed in the paper. 8.4 Risk Aversion on the Part of Borrowers or Lenders The paper assumes risk neutrality by firms and banks. In traditional theory, if equity markets exist this is shown to be a reasonable approximation for all firms. In most LDCs, however, such markets do not exist and both firm equity and loan demand may be affected by degree of risk aversion. I would hypothesize that, apart from complicating the derivation of the loan demand curve, this would not make any essential difference to the qualitative analysis. -/ The problem is less important in the case of banks if they can pool their risk across different firms. This is possible if the returns of different firms are not highly correlated and if each loan is a small proportion of the total loans outstanding. In the case of traditional agriculture, however, the returns of different borrowers may be highly correlated. This would require incorporation of bank risk aversion. The
 - 138 - model can be extended to include a tradeoff between the banks' expected profits and the variance in these profits. If firms, are risk neutral, preliminary analysis suggests that the loan size would be lower and the interest rate and collateral higher if banks are risk averse than if they are risk neutral. 8.5 Multiperiod Loans Finally it would be possible to consider the question of loan terms and the choice between short and long term loans, if the model were extended to a multiperiod framework. The structure of the model is quite suitable for this extension. 8.6 Implications for Entrepreneurial Savings The model has implications for equity contributions and entreprenurial savings which are not touched on in the paper. Consider a situation in which equity markets are highly imperfect or non-existent. Assume that the marginal cost of equity or entrepreneurial saving is non- decreasing with equity. Now suppose that government puts a ceiling on loan interest rates which is an effective ceiling for certain borrowers who would otherwise be charged higher rates. For a given level of equity the analysis of chapter IV shows tht collateral rises and loan amounts fall. The latter would in turn imply a rise in the marginal product of the loan plus equity above the marginal cost of equity. Equilibrium would require an increase in equity contribution and consequently in entrepreneurial savings. Similar results follow if ceilings are put on deposit interest rates. This means that a ceiling on interest rates may raise savings instead of reducing them, as traditionally assumed.

doc.repnme: The nature of credit markets in developing countries : a framework for policy analysis
doc.abstracts: The central purpose of the paper is to analyze various forms of government intervention in the loan market in terms of their effect on efficiency. This provides the essential basis for evaluating and judging these policies. It also shows where earlier policy prescriptions are correct, incomplete or wrong. One of the implications of the paper is that the credit market differs fundamentally from the market for ordinary goods and services. Consequently conventional analysis of the loan markets, based on theory applicable to these goods, can be misleading even when similar prescriptions are reached. This is because the similarity may be restricted to special circumstances. Another important highlight of the paper is the vital role of collateral in the loan market. These two issues are addressed in the introductory discussion on the special nature of credit markets, which forms an important prerequisite for understanding the subsequent section and the rest of the paper.
